text: @cojames literalism is the lowest form of non-wit.
@robertpostill it was such an inviting window.
never actually met anyone with the surname Bloggs. Do they exist?
@robertpostill people are complex, no question. but it's not P=?NP.
@status_line watching Trainspotting again?
@joshprice I'll grant you that it's very helpful for vaguely-specified, imprecise problems of the sort that come up around humans.
@joshprice I disagree vociferously. You won't derive quicksort or write correct concurrent code because of TDD.
@dysinger it's something I go back and forth on. more regular syntax would be nice, but laziness means you write fewer macros anyway.
@whalec Pervert. #morningsareforstayingawakeuntil
@shimweasel asymptotically approaches 3.6.5
TDD is an excellent way to solve trivial problems.
@dysinger you might find liskell interesting.
Watching Jonah Lomu highlight reels and remembering exactly how much he changed every game he played in.
@donsbot weird not to have 0.0.1 on cabal, though. source tarballs are so 90s.
classic case of the subtitle being so much better than the title. http://pubs.doc.ic.ac.uk/irulan-tr/
@jamesbritt good-o. looking at using FFI instead, now - I want to remove the compile-time dependence, so you could install a ruby after.
@chrislloyd annotations for me are more about cementing my understanding. it's not stuff that should be in the original book.
@jamesbritt your painstaking install notes never fail to instil in me a desire to make them obsolete. First on the hit-list: c2hs.
@schappim congratulations, man, that's awesome
@azzamallow the bogan is strong in this one.
@chrislloyd heh. possibly, but can you imagine annotating hardback knuth? it'd be like drawing a moustache on the mona lisa.
@amosrobinson and really, why would you want to be directing lots of traffic? In my day, a handwritten note was fine!
@chrislloyd Heh. Still not completely convinced - I have a beautiful hardback copy of Knuth I'm almost afraid to open.
this code should not be set aside lightly, but thrown with great force
"100 per cent accurate - no overblocking, no underblocking and no impact on speeds". Aw, Conroy is so cute.
@lightningdb @chrislloyd bollocks, mine had justification! plot exposition!
@lightningdb I think of it as a travel book, so I'd get the paperback. You won't be afraid of annotating it then, either.
@whalec oh. objective c. *makes face*
@whalec it's a big passive-aggressive "fuck-you" from the machine, really.
adding mocks to feature files strips away the last little bit of contact I had with reality. What am I testing again?
@helenrazer is the horse-shaped smear on the ground because you're Homosexual?
so very sick of indirection
@simonmar you're now in my prioritised queue of people to write angry replies to.
wish you could compose point-free functions in ruby
can't argue ♺ @timfreedman:  Saw Amanda Palmer last night Opera House. Great songs, but the crowd is like a bunch of stalkers.
@pigworker it is a scientifically proven FACT that midgets can't write Haskell, regardless of meteorological crockery.
@pigworker massive, difficult to redirect, awe-inspiring, entertaining and a source of mindboggling amounts of excrement?
quitting while i still have working graphics. I can buy an ethernet-usb adaptor or something. *stepping away from computer*
@freshtonic a little distro for big men, hey?
@freshtonic "Perhaps if my distro is compact enough, someone will finally love me..."
@freshtonic unkind comments about distros for celibates do spring to mind.
@liedra so was I! #floggingadeadhorse #fattysmearontheground #tits #chortle
@liedra then put a shirt on, dear girl. You'll catch your death!
@madradish now I know how non-programmers feel when I talk about typeclasses and closures. Frogging? Doctoring?
@whalec you're using a Ruby DSL to test a Lua wrapper of a C layer around Windows device drivers? Yeah, ecstatic :P
@schallkiste sehr schlect. Haskell ist fantastisch! (apologies for my terrible German...)
@donsbot more like eating nothing but plum pudding...
listening to a whole album of metal feels like playing a video game composed entirely of boss fights.
@filterfish nostalgist.
Can't believe I needed William Gibson to tell me @helenrazer was on twitter
@filterfish heresy! it's a quite pleasant album, but mezzanine is basically perfect...
@freshtonic it's not bad, is it? Not Mezzanine, of course, but nothing is. Did you go to the gig?
art, science, useless dichotomies... http://www.ribbonfarm.com/2010/03/23/amy-lin-and-the-ancient-eye/

rat brain organising to control robot: http://bit.ly/aG4GgB amazing example of plasticity in action.
@joshprice yep. trying to get back into riding to work... rode it to the last hack night, too.
@joshprice tourer. I took it around thailand/cambodia/vietnam, survived everything but airport handlers.
@geezusfreeek excellently put, you bastard:)
@geezusfreeek your test obligations set the requirements for your unit tests, though. obviously you need _some_ unit tests.
@joshprice I got a nice one built for me at Europa cycles. It's hard getting a big bike otherwise.
@geezusfreeek a complex function imposes a higher testing obligation than the definition of 'map', but probably has fewer strong properties.
@geezusfreeek there's a difference between "stronger properties" and "higher testing obligation".
@geezusfreeek (assuming of course that we're testing things that are different in some structural way...)
@geezusfreeek I can come up with more testable properties for the amazon website than I can for addition. Does that make amazon simpler?
good code requires few unit tests: http://andreyf.tumblr.com/post/459323557/good-code-needs-few-unit-tests
